title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

· Gulls

· Wading Birds

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify a population of organisms that receives the least amount of transferred energy, such as any of the following:

· Ospreys

· Bald eagles

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why a decrease in the osprey population could likely lead to an increase in the bald eagle population in the short term, such as any of the following:

· Bald eagles and ospreys compete for large fish; if there are fewer ospreys, there would be more food available for the bald eagles or less competition for the prey.

· Bald eagles and ospreys specialize in the same prey, so if there are fewer ospreys, there would be more food available for the bald eagles or less competition for the prey.

The response explains why a decrease in the osprey population could likely lead to an increase in the bald eagle population in the short term, such as one of the following:

· Bald eagles and ospreys compete for large fish; if there are fewer ospreys, there would be more food available for the bald eagles or less competition for the prey.

· Bald eagles and ospreys specialize in the same prey, so if there are fewer ospreys, there would be more food available for the bald eagles or less competition for the prey.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem in the Chesapeake Bay that results from the high volume of automobile traffic in Baltimore, such as any of the following:

· Oil/antifreeze/fuel spills/rubber/brake pad material can run off and pollute the bay.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a realistic solution to the problem identified in part (e), such as any of the following:

· Increasing the use of public transportation/carpooling will decrease the number of vehicles on the road, which will decrease the amount of pollution/litter from vehicles.

· Adding bike lanes/walking paths in urban areas will encourage biking/walking rather than driving, which will decrease the amount of pollution from vehicles.

· Incorporating vegetative buffer strips along roadways, waterways, or the bay will prevent the runoff of pollutants.

· Reducing urban sprawl will decrease the vehicle miles driven, which will decrease the amount of pollution/litter from vehicles.

· Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs will decrease the amount of litter from vehicles working its way into the bay.

The response makes a claim that proposes a realistic solution to the problem identified in part (e), such as one of the following:

· Increasing the use of public transportation/carpooling will decrease the number of vehicles on the road, which will decrease the amount of pollution/litter from vehicles.

· Adding bike lanes/walking paths in urban areas will encourage biking/walking rather than driving, which will decrease the amount of pollution from vehicles.

· Incorporating vegetative buffer strips along roadways, waterways, or the bay will prevent the runoff of pollutants.

· Reducing urban sprawl will decrease the vehicle miles driven, which will decrease the amount of pollution/litter from vehicles.

· Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs will decrease the amount of litter from vehicles working its way into the bay.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one additional benefit that could result from the implementation of the solution proposed in part (f), such as any of the following:

Increasing the use of public transportation/carpooling (solution in part (f)).

· More efficient use of resources (e.g., passenger/miles is better for buses and light rail than for cars)

· Less vehicular traffic reduces greenhouse gas emissions

· Less air pollution benefits human health

· Decreases noise pollution from traffic

Adding bike lanes/walking paths in urban areas (solution in part (f)).

· No fossil fuel used for transport

· Source of exercise

Incorporating vegetative buffer strips along roadways, waterways, or the bay (solution in part (f)).

· Increased vegetation reduces heat island effect

· Provides habitat

· Decreases noise pollution

Reducing urban sprawl (solution in part (f)).

· Denser communities foster more walking/exercise/health benefits/social interaction

Controlling litter via stricter fines or litter cleanup programs (solution in part (f)).

· Increases tourism

· Decreases vermin

· Decreases mosquito-borne disease

· Can prevent flooding (trash may accumulate in and clog drains)

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one unintended consequence that the widespread use of antibiotics and growth hormones in the poultry industry can have on the Chesapeake Bay, such as any of the following:

· Antibiotics and hormones allow for high-intensity poultry farming, leading to large amounts of wastes that can run off into the bay.

· Antibiotics can be toxic to some aquatic organisms (e.g., algae).

· Natural and artificial hormones can affect growth and reproduction of some aquatic organisms (e.g., frogs, fish).

The response describes one unintended consequence that the widespread use of antibiotics and growth hormones in the poultry industry can have on the Chesapeake Bay, such as one of the following:

· Antibiotics and hormones allow for high-intensity poultry farming, leading to large amounts of wastes that can run off into the bay.

· Antibiotics can be toxic to some aquatic organisms (e.g., algae).

· Natural and artificial hormones can affect growth and reproduction of some aquatic organisms (e.g., frogs, fish).
